<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 193, 368, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 170, 905, 187]]<|/det|>
0625/21  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
May/June 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 216, 905, 231]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 246, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 336, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 353, 115, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 352, 599, 369]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 368, 907, 400]]<|/det|>
For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 397, 579, 414]]<|/det|>
Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 414, 277, 429]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 429, 868, 460]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 459, 327, 475]]<|/det|>
Do not use correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 475, 364, 491]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 491, 329, 507]]<|/det|>
You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 507, 670, 524]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 570, 616]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 40. Each correct answer will score one mark. Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 922, 106]]<|/det|>
A cart has a mass of \(10\mathrm{kg}.\) A boy pushes on the cart horizontally with a force of \(50\mathrm{N}.\) The cart accelerates at \(0.50\mathrm{m / s}^2.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 116, 490, 135]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 559, 920, 593]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 803, 89]]<|/det|>
Very small pollen grains are suspended in water. A bright light shines from the side.

<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 613, 663, 631]]<|/det|>
Why are small gaps left between the metal rails of a railway track?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 642, 133, 660]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 642, 534, 660]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 696, 541, 714]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 722, 546, 740]]<|/det|>
to allow for contraction of the rails on a cold day

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 536, 89]]<|/det|>
A block of metal absorbs 2000 J of thermal energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 567, 120]]<|/det|>
The temperature of the block rises from \(10^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(20^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 378, 151]]<|/det|>
The mass of the block is \(2.0 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 505, 180]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 191, 134, 210]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 191, 767, 210]]<|/det|>
50 J/(kg°C) B 100 J/(kg°C) C 200 J/(kg°C) D 400 J/(kg°C)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 237, 106, 255]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 237, 598, 255]]<|/det|>
Which statement about boiling and evaporation is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 265, 134, 282]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 265, 720, 282]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 292, 134, 310]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 332, 611, 350]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 359, 134, 377]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 359, 574, 376]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 404, 106, 421]]<|/det|>
<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 403, 373, 421]]<|/det|>
A metal rod is heated at end X.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 432, 616, 509]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 523, 500, 541]]<|/det|>
Why does end Y of the metal rod become hot?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 552, 134, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 552, 920, 584]]<|/det|>
Energy is transferred from end X of the rod to end Y by vibration of positive ions and by movement of electrons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 593, 134, 611]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 593, 870, 611]]<|/det|>
Energy is transferred from end X of the rod to end Y by movement of positive ions only.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 619, 134, 637]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 619, 848, 637]]<|/det|>
Energy is transferred from end X of the rod to end Y by vibration of positive ions only.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 645, 134, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 645, 843, 663]]<|/det|>
Energy is transferred from end X of the rod to end Y by movement of electrons only.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 719, 861, 737]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 744, 843, 762]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 774, 559, 792]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 447, 88]]<|/det|>
A student rubs a plastic rod with a cloth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 423, 119]]<|/det|>
The rod becomes positively charged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 381, 149]]<|/det|>
What has happened to the rod?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 161, 134, 178]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 161, 346, 177]]<|/det|>
It has gained electrons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 187, 134, 203]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 186, 333, 203]]<|/det|>
It has gained protons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 214, 134, 231]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 214, 322, 230]]<|/det|>
It has lost electrons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 240, 134, 257]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 240, 306, 256]]<|/det|>
It has lost protons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 284, 106, 301]]<|/det|>
<label>30</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 284, 500, 301]]<|/det|>
An isolated metal sphere is positively charged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 313, 690, 330]]<|/det|>
It is then brought near to another isolated metal sphere that is neutral.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 339, 809, 448]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 460, 922, 494]]<|/det|>
What happens to the charges on the neutral sphere as the positively charged sphere is brought close to it?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 504, 134, 522]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 504, 856, 522]]<|/det|>
Some positive charges move to the left and some negative charges move to the right.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 531, 134, 549]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 530, 856, 549]]<|/det|>
Some positive charges move to the right and some negative charges move to the left.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 558, 131, 575]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 556, 811, 575]]<|/det|>
Some positive charges move to the right, but the negative charges do not move.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 584, 133, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 583, 803, 600]]<|/det|>
The positive charges do not move, but some negative charges move to the left.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 626, 106, 644]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 626, 646, 644]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the resistance of a metal wire is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 655, 133, 673]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 655, 920, 688]]<|/det|>
The resistance is directly proportional to its length and directly proportional to its cross-sectional area.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 696, 133, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 696, 920, 728]]<|/det|>
The resistance is directly proportional to its length and inversely proportional to its cross-sectional area.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 739, 133, 756]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 738, 920, 770]]<|/det|>
The resistance is inversely proportional to its length and directly proportional to its cross-sectional area.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 780, 133, 797]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 780, 920, 810]]<|/det|>
The resistance is inversely proportional to its length and inversely proportional to its cross-sectional area.
